title-group.article-title: The only species of Calvisia (Phasmatodea, Necrosciinae) from China, with a new synonymy and additional descriptions

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
The only species of
Calvisia
( Phasmatodea , Necrosciinae ) from China , with a new synonymy and additional descriptions
HAO-RAN GAO 1,2 , CHEN WANG 1,3 , QIAN-LE LU 4 , LE LIANG 5 , PEI-LIN LIAO 6 & YA-JIN LI 1,7,*

Department of Entomology, College of Plant Protection, Yunnan Agricultural University, Kunming 650201, China

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Calvisia
is a colorful winged stick insect genus consisting of 6 subgenera and 44 species widely distributed in temperate and tropical Asia.
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
was discovered in Mêdog, Xizang ( Tibet ), China and is so far the only species recorded from China . We here propose that
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
is a synonym of
C. fuscoalata
after checking type specimens of both species. New materials studied are deposited in Yunnan Agricultural University, China ( YNAU ).

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Key words:
Calvisia
, Necrosciini
, synonym ,
China

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Calvisia
( Necrosciinae : Necrosciini) in China is known as “jade stick insects ( ŦDZ )”, showing beautiful and aposematic coloration among species in this subfamily. At present, this genus contains 6 subgenera and 44 species distributed in temperate and tropical Asia (
,
,
).

C. fuscoalata
was first described by
based on a male specimen from Sikkim , India who gave the following features: body green; 2 elevations on the mesonotum; forewings green; hindwings with triangular white spots; abdomen red with green apex; anal segment round with a middle fork; operculum with 3 denticles on apex; cerci curved with pointed apex; profemora straight.
thought
C. fuscoalata
had a relationship with
Tagesoidea tages ( Westwood, 1859 )
and considered
C. fuscoalata
as a “transitional species” between
Calvisia
and
Tagesoidea
.
described
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
from Mêdog County, southern foothills of the Himalayas, China , and he compared it with
C. fuscoalata
referring to the following 3 major diagnosis characteristics: 1) middle of mesonotum have a pair of conspicuous blunt conical spines; 2) base of forewings with a yellow spot; 3) the costal area of hindwings brown with 9 white triangular spots on the margin. Two of the three characters identified by
were matched by
, and only the yellow spot at the basal of the forewing had not been mentioned. This problem may be due to the sex of the specimen as well as the way the specimen was stored; the coloration of this species fades after death. Molecular work (especially mitochondrial genome) of
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
has been undertaken recently and provided new insights into the huge subfamily Necrosciinae (
, Song et al. 2018,
).

For nearly 30 years, the beautiful Mêdog jade stick insect
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
had been recognized as the only species of
Calvisia
in China and had recently been included in the “
List of terrestrial wild animals of important ecological, scientific and social value in China
” (
). Specimens of
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
from the type-locality, Mêdog County, had recently been collected, examined in the laboratory and compared with type specimens from Shanghai Entomological Museum, Chinese Academy of Science ( SIE ). We here propose that
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
is a synonym of
C. fuscoalata
and the opportunity is taken to redescribe the female of this species in more detail.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
The specimens were collected during night surveys with the help of head-torches. The systematic treatment follows Phasmida Species File (Version 5.0/5.0), an online database by
. Morphological terminology follows that of
and the terminology of hindwing veins follows
and
. All measurements are given in mm. Photographs of specimens were taken using a Sony (Sony Corporation, Japan ) a6300 with LAOWA ( Anhui Changgeng Optics Technology Co., Ltd., China ) 60 mm F2.8 Macro and Sony 30 mm F3.5 Macro. Photos were improved by Adobe (Adobe Systems Incorporated, USA , adobe.com) Photoshop 2020 and Adobe Lightroom Classic. The distribution map was supported by SimpleMappr (
). The new materials studied were deposited in the Yunnan Agricultural University ( YNAU ).

Calvisia fusco-alata Redtenbacher, 1908: 567
[then as
fuscoalata
, original description; type locality: Sikkim , India ]; Giglio-Tos, 1914: 423 [; Brock, 1998: 31 [ type data].
Otte & Brock, 2005: 77
[Catalogue];
Mandal & Yadav, 2010: 8
;
Seow-Choen, 2016: 55
[in subgenus
Conocalvisia
];
Brock & Büscher, 2022: 531
[Catalogue].

,
2.VII.1980
, leg. Yin-Tao Jin , Jian-Yi Wu ( SIE ).

.

.

15.VIII.2023
, leg. Feng-Qi Guo ( YNAU )
.
1♀ , China , Xizang Autonomous Region ( Tibet ), Nyingchi City , Mêdog County , Mêdog Town , nr. Guoguotang Great Ben , Yarang Village , 29°17′56.92″N , 95°16′47.93″E , alt.
725m
,
8.VII.2023
, leg. Zhi-Sheng Zhang , Lu-Yu Wang , Qian-Le Lu , Xu-Long Chen ( YNAU )
.

Coloration. Female (
A-F, 2A&C, 3A-C).
General uniform green, anterior margin of pronotum light yellow; median area of posterior margin on pronotum with a yellow spot. Apex of coxae and femora yellow. Carinae of femora with intermittent black spots. Arolium are all brown. The veins on both forewings and hindwings are dark. The basal part of tegmen with a yellow spot. Costal area of hindwings green but outer with narrow blue margin; in ventral view, costal area of hindwings is blue (
). The median area of tergites I-VIII with a big dark spot; the rest area with red coloration but not reach the margins, the margins green or pale yellow.

Measurements of female (mm). [Including the data by Bi (1993) ] Body: 57.3–65.0; Head: 4.0–4.3; Pronotum: 2.9–3.1; Mesonotum: 6.8–7.0; Profemora: 14.2–15.0; Mesofemora: 11.1–13.0; Metafemora: 15.8–16.5; Protibiae: 13.2–13.7; Mesotibiae: 10.5–10.9; Metatibiae: 14.8–15.3; Tegmen: 4.6–5.0; Hindwing: 50.0–51.1.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Retdenbacher (1908) thought that
C. fuscoalata
was strongly related to
Tagesoidea tages
, both found in Sikkim , India , probably because of the similar color pattern: general green body; black wings with white spots. But
T. tages
can be distinguished by the following characteristics: smaller body; orange and unbranched radius ( R ) veins; large white area or unicolor dark at the base of the hindwings, but with a row of white spots located submarginally (
).

Accurate species identification is undoubtedly the first step in biodiversity conservation.Although
C. medogensis
syn. nov.
was included in “
List of terrestrial wild animals of important ecological, scientific and social value in China
”, there are still no population investigations or conservation biology studies on this species. The distribution map ( Fig. 4 ) shows that this species may potentially be found in the southern Himalayas, including northeastern India , Bhutan , and even Nepal . This species, although not endemic to China , is the only distribution of the genus in China , and is the highest latitude distribution of the genus. In conclusion, we think it is right that this species is protected by Chinese law, but its rarity and population status remain unknown.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: Our great thanks are given to Zhi-Sheng Zhang, Lu-Yu Wang and Xu-Long Chen from Southwest University of China , Chongqing , China for providing materials to study. Our thanks also go to Han-Qiang Wang ( SIE ) for help with type specimens. We wish to thank Hong-Rui Zhang ( YNAU ) for pre-reading the manuscript and providing valuable advice. We are very grateful to the editor Thies Büscher ( Germany ) and the reviewer Paul Brock ( UK ) for their careful consideration and useful comments.
